title: Week 9 Football Roundup
text: PICTURES: Best Fans of Week 9 - CLICK HERE State-ranked powers battle The area had four games featuring two state-ranked teams, and none was bigger than Class 2 No. 1 Lamar handing Class 4 No. 2 Carl Junction a 56-34 loss on their way out of the Big 8 . It was the first Big 8 title in program history for Lamar. Lamar senior running back Danny Embry had 126 yards rushing and four touchdowns to lead the way. Senior running back Luke Hardman ran for 115 yards and two touchdowns on only four carries and caught a 46-yard pass that set up a touchdown. Lamar quarterbacks Stuart McKarus and Matt Whyman combined for 4 of 4 passing for 156 yards. Carl Junction was led by Dominnic Burnett and his 144 yards and three touchdowns on the ground. Bulldog quarterback Ryan Devore was 23-for-42 for 193 yards through the air. The loss dropped Carl Junction to the No. 4 seed in its district setting up a likely semifinal matchup with Webb City. Class 3 No. 4 Reeds Spring gave Class 4 No. 10 Bolivar all it wanted for much of the game, but fell 50-27 after the Liberators scored 30 unanswered to end the game and extend their COC Small dominance. Connor Sechler was 15-for-18 for 289 yards through the air in the win. Aaron Samek had 15 carries for 135 yards and four touchdowns. Johnny Scott had seven catches for 132 yards. The loss didn’t hurt Reeds Spring’s district seeding as the Wolves will be the No. 1 seed. Bolivar bumped up to the No. 3 seed in its district. It took double overtime, but Class 1 No. 7 Lockwood knocked off Class 1 No. 10 Jasper 38-30 on the road . Lockwood quarterback Ben Schnelle was 15-for-23 for 269 yards and one touchdown through the air. He added 75 yards and two touchdowns on 14 carries on the ground. Jasper’s quarterback Blake Jeffries was 17-for-29 for 244 yards and four touchdowns through the air with 75 yards on the ground. Class 1 No. 9 Thayer proved it is threat to make a deep postseason run by going on the road and handling Mountain Grove 38-14 , which was the Bobcats’ first win over the Panthers since 2011. Thayer took a 24-0 lead in the first half and never looked back. Both teams will be top seeds as district play starts next week. All other state-ranked teams roll None of the rest of the rest of the area’s seven state-ranked teams lost, and just one of the teams played a game within a touchdown. Class 5 No. 8 Carthage went on the road and took a 36-29 win off of Willard . Star quarterback Alex Derryberry made his return for the Blue Tigers and was sharp. The senior was 9-for-14 for 213 yards and three touchdowns through the air. He also gained 83 yards and scored a touchdown on the ground. Class 4 No. 1 Webb City rolled past Branson 49-7 and is the top seed in its district. Class 2 No. 2 Skyline backed up its big win over Marionville with a 53-18 victory against Tipton. Tyler Swearington was money scoring four touchdowns on just seven touches that included a kick return, punt return, rushing and receiving touchdown. He also recovered a fumble, as the Tigers claimed their district’s No. 1 seed. Jacob LaSalle had the stat-line of the night in Class 1 No. 4 Marionville’s 54-14 dismantling of Stockton. LaSalle was 28-for-40 for 387 yards and eight touchdowns through the air. He also had 11 tackles, a forced fumble and fumble recovery. Tanner Wright was LaSalle’s top target with 10 catches for 158 yards and three touchdowns. Lathan Kerans also hauled in three touchdowns on 96 yards. Josh Pruett continues to be a star, as he led Class 2 No. 5 MV-BT/Liberty past Houston 63-7. He threw for 193 yards and four touchdowns, and he rushed for 74 yards and two more touchdowns. Marcos Rodriguez was also productive for Liberty with 15 carries for 65 yards and two touchdowns. Class 6 No. 7 Kickapoo sewed up the No. 1 seed in its district with a 49-12 win over Waynesville. Sam Hall carried the ball seven times for 173 yards and two scores, as Class 4 No. 8 West Plains breezed by Rolla 60-13. Games with major district implications No game had a larger bearing on district seeding than Republic’s 42-27 win over Nixa . With the win, Republic moved up to the district’s No. 1 seed and Nixa fell all the way from No. 1 to No. 3. Jerney Jones was the story for Republic as he carried the ball 25 times for 216 yards and three touchdowns. The team that leap-frogged Nixa into the second spot was Parkview, who held off Lebanon in a 42-35 win. Anthony Riley rushed for 246 yards and four touchdowns in the win. Fellow senior Chaviz Nguyen added another 175 yards on the ground for the Vikings. Strafford started the day as the No. 6 seed in its district, but finished it as the No. 4 spot on the strength of a 20-7 win over Ash Grove . All of those scores came courtesy of Jacob Eden who rushed for 226 yards and three touchdowns on 21 carries. All three touchdowns occurred in the third quarter and came from at least 40 yards out. Central’s big 28-26 double-overtime win over Mount Vernon secured a district home game for the Bulldogs . They batted away a two-point conversion attempt to secure the win. Garrett King led the way for the Bulldogs with 233 yards and two touchdowns on 26 carries. The Bulldogs will face Glendale in the opening round of districts. The Falcons were 60-41 winners over Camdenton. It marked just the fourth win over the Lakers in program history and first since 1991. VIDEO: In the Zone - Week 9 Recap Rest of the area’s games Neosho rode Devin Hames and his 26 carries for 221 yards and three touchdowns to a 38-21 win over Ozark. Joplin held Hillcrest to just 41 yards of offense and four first downs in a 52-0 win. The Eagles are the No. 2 seed in their Class 6 district behind Kickapoo. Springfield Catholic used Mason Robertson’s 146 yards and three touchdowns along with Robbie Avila’s 177 yards and one touchdown to take down Marshfield 34-28. Marshfield quarterback Jordan Dean was strong in the loss going 25-for-40 for 320 yards and two touchdowns through the air along with 121 yards and two touchdowns on the ground. Salem cruised by Cabool 41-7 behind Derek McClain’s 13 carries for 155 yards and two touchdowns. Ava had 359 rushing yards as a team and five different players rush for a touchdown in its 47-6 win over Willow Springs. Monett continued its strong season by beating McDonald County 45-6. Michael Brand had 112 yards and two touchdowns for the Cubs on the ground. Ian Meyer had 167 yards and a touchdown through the air. Cameron Witt rushed for 50 yards and had 50 yards receiving and two touchdowns. Cassville’s River Phelps ran wild in a 40-12 Big 8 win over Seneca. The Wildcats’ back had 237 yards and five touchdowns. Pierce City’s Jamie Logan had 12 carries for 138 yards and two touchdowns in a 27-7 win over Sarcoxie. Aurora’s Payton Evans continued to prove why he is the Big 8’s best quarterback in a 47-7 victory over East Newton. Evans was a perfect five-for-five for 153 yards and two touchdowns through the air. Lance Molz continued his late-season surge with 275 yards and four touchdowns on 16 carries in a 56-28 win over Adrian. Other Scores
